definitions.definition: towards a place or position that is in front

examples.text: She **leaned forward** and kissed him on the cheek.
He took two steps forwards.
They ran forward to welcome her.
The procession slowly **moved forward**.
Turn your wrists so that your palms face forward.
He stands by the fire, rocking **backward and forward**.

definitions.definition: towards the future; ahead in time

examples.text: **Looking forward**, we hope to expand our operations in several of our overseas branches.
The next scene takes the story forwards five years.
The series moves back and forward through time.
from this day forward
We consider this agreement to be an important **step forward**.
Cutting our costs is the only **way forward**.
We are not getting any **further forward** with the discussion.
The project will **go forward** *(= continue)* as planned.
The 21st century has seen trade between the two countries leap forward.
It was decided to bring the meeting forward two weeks.

definitions.definition: in or towards the front part of a ship or plane

examples.text: The main cabin is situated forward of *(= in front of)* the mast.

definitions.definition: from one place or position to another and back again many times

examples.text: She rocked backwards and forwards on her chair.
The film skips backwards and forwards through time.

definitions.definition: in the future, starting from now

examples.text: We have a very solid financial position going forward.
The strategy going forward is still undecided.
Moving forward, we need to have a real plan.

definitions.definition: to make a great effort to do something, especially if it is difficult or you are feeling tired
to change the time shown by clocks, usually by one hour, when the time changes officially, for example at the beginning and end of summer

examples.text: Remember to put your clocks back tonight.

wordOrigin: Old English forweard (in the sense ‘towards the future’, as in from this day forward), variant of forthweard (see forth, -ward).
